title: Suggest `std::ptr::read()` when trying to move out of raw pointer

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org --> [playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=6e24f5c0d122fb7679af429e9a9b1e78)

```rust
struct NonCopyType;

fn main() {
    let v = NonCopyType;
    let ptr = &v as *const NonCopyType;
    let _moved = unsafe { *ptr };
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0507]: cannot move out of `*ptr` which is behind a raw pointer
 --> src/main.rs:6:27
  |
6 |     let _moved = unsafe { *ptr };
  |                           ^^^^
  |                           |
  |                           move occurs because `*ptr` has type `NonCopyType`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
  |                           help: consider borrowing here: `&*ptr`
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
It would be nice if the compiler would suggest to use `std::ptr::read()`:

```
error[E0507]: cannot move out of `*ptr` which is behind a raw pointer
 --> src/main.rs:6:27
  |
6 |     let _moved = unsafe { *ptr };
  |                           ^^^^
  |                           |
  |                           move occurs because `*ptr` has type `NonCopyType`, which does not implement the `Copy` trait
  |                           help: consider borrowing here: `&*ptr`
  |                           help: consider using `std::ptr::read()`: `std::ptr::read(ptr)`
```

<!--
If the problem is not self-explanatory, please provide a rationale for the
change.
-->
